text:
So you've tried every productivity hack out
there.

You've done a productivity course and built
your own productivity system.
But you still can't stop procrastinating.

And you start to wonder... "what's wrong with
me??"
It's not you.

It's the procrastination-productivity myth
that's been holding you back.

And until very recently, this was happening
to me too.
So I'm here to do a little myth-busting.
Procrastination doesn’t mean you’re lazy

There's technically, uh, nothing wrong with
leaving things to the last minute, if you
actually do them at the last minute

This is Jorge Cham, a cartoonist and creator
of PhD Comics – which explores procrastination
a lot

I consider myself an expert procrastinator
to the, to the point where it's sort of a
way of life for me to be honest.

Which makes Jorge very experienced in what
people get wrong about procrastination.

You know, my big thing is that there's a big
difference between procrastination and laziness.

You know, laziness is when you don't want
to do anything procrastination, you just don't
want to do it now.

We get stuck in the procrastination guilt
trap

Now, this distinction matters because if we
think that we’re lazy and then we start

to act in a lazy way, we just start feeling
bad about ourselves.
You could say that we feed our inner critic.

So, we get stuck in this procrastination guilt
trap where we feel bad that we’re procrastinating,

we procrastinate more, and then we just feel
worse about ourselves.
And that is not helpful.

And being able to manage our inner critic
is so crucial in being able to manage procrastination,

because so much of procrastination is actually
caused by our thoughts and feelings.

So, now with a pad of paper and a giant llama,
I’m going to illaminate– sorry illuminate
four ways that you can overcome procrastination.
Forgive yourself.

For starters it’s super important to forgive
yourself.

So, self-compassion is really, really crucial
to getting out of the guilt trap: And research

shows that students who forgave themselves
for procrastinating when they were meant to

be studying for an exam were less likely to
procrastinate the next time their exams came
around.

Stop using “should” statements
Next up, we can all try to stop using “should”
statements.

So, your inner critic loves to use “should”
statements, so we “should” be getting

a certain amount of exercise today, or we
“should” be following this morning routine.

I had a professor who really challenged us
to think about what the word “should”
means.

Like when we say things like, Oh, I really
should be, um, working on this, or I really
should be cleaning my kitchen.

If you sort of think about what the word “should”
means.

It's really not a word that makes a lot of
sense by itself.

If you catch yourself using a “should”
statement, you can try to reframe it with

a little bit more self-compassion: So you
might think if you do actually enjoy exercising,

you might think that, “exercising makes
me feel good.”

Or you might think, “following this morning
routine actually helps me manage stress.”
Imagine working through the task

Another thing you can do is imagine working
through a task.

We often use procrastination to avoid discomfort,
which could be having a tough conversation,

thinking through a hard problem, or something
like sending a difficult email.

One way that we can get better at both starting
and doing these tasks is by sitting down and

imagining working through that task, working
through the thing we have been avoiding doing

in practice just by thinking through all of
the steps in our head.

It helps to do it mentally before we do it
physically.

And finding things to help you deal with discomfort
is really useful as well – so this can be

breathing exercises, or meditation, or maybe
just binge watching Schitt’s Creek.
And finally, give yourself permission to rest.

So, we often procrastinate by going to get
a snack or check our phones or find ourselves

browsing the web because we don’t schedule
enough breaks into our daily routine.

So, if you’re working from home, or studying,
plan to take a break every 15 mins for every
hour of work.

I know that seems like a lot, but if you schedule
more of these small breaks, you’ll be less

likely to procrastinate by going to take breaks
yourself.

Now my main message here is don’t beat yourself
up about productivity!

Hustle culture and thinking that you need
to optimize everything can be really harmful.

For me, thinking about why I was procrastinating,
independent of productivity helped me realize

why I was delaying everything and how I could
better deal with those tasks.
I could better deal with them and myself.

Procrastination is its own beast, and the
techniques to overcome it are way different
from being more productive.
So remember that, and good luck.
